subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The phenomenon referred to as ‘left dislocation’ (LD) is exemplified in (1). LD is characterized by the presence of a phrase in the first position of the clause which is connected with that clause through the intermediary of some anaphoric element referred to as the resumptive element (see chapter 55).
(1) John, I like him.
In (1) the DP John, appears in sentence initial position, to the left of the material contained within the clause, and is connected with the clause through the intermediary of the pronoun him.
In LD constructions, the clause is considered to be ‘about’ the left dislocated element. This is often referred to as the aboutness requirement.

subsection.heading: 2 Types of left dislocation
subsection.p: It has been observed that there are various instances of LD across languages or even within a language. In addition to (1), we find constructions of the type illustrated in (2) (see Van Haaften et al. 1983). As can be seen in (1–2), the resumptive element can be a regular personal pronoun as in English, or a demonstrative pronoun as in Dutch (2a) or a clitic pronoun as in languages such as Italian, Romanian, Spanish, Hebrew, Arabic, and Greek (2b):

(2)
a. Die man die ken ik niet.
the man that know I not
‘That man, I don't know him.’
b. Ton Jani den ton ksero.
the-acc John-acc neg cl-acc know-1sg
‘John, I do not know him.’

(2a) is known as Contrastive Left Dislocation (CLD), while (2b) is referred to as Clitic Left Dislocation (CLLD). CLD is a typical Germanic construction. A further type of Left Dislocation is Hanging Topic Left Dislocation (HTLD), illustrated in (1) and again in (3) with a Spanish example, where the role of the resumptive element is performed by an epithet: 1

(3)
Bernardo estoy segura que nadie confia en ese idiota.
Bernardo (I) am sure that nobody has confidence in that idiot
‘(As for) Bernardo, I am sure that nobody has confidence in that idiot.’
Hanging topics can be introduced by an ‘as for’ phrase (4). However, as (3) shows, the presence of these phrases is not obligatory:
(4) As for the circus the elephants are fine.

All types of LD respect the aboutness requirement. The aboutness requirement is usually met by the resumptive element, but in some languages a weaker, purely semantic form is sufficient. This seems to be true in French, as pointed out in Hirschbühler (1975):

(5)
Oh tu sais moi la bicyclette je n’ aime pas me fatiguer.
oh you know me the bicycle I neg like not me tire
‘Oh you know, me, the bicycle I don't like to tire myself.’
This type of LD is referred to as Loose Aboutness Left Dislocation (LALD) in Van Riemsdijk (1997a).

As Van Riemsdijk (1997a) points out, much of the variation among these types can be related in some form or other to the resumptive element. In particular, different types of LD arise depending on the obligatoriness of the resumptive element, its form, and whether it is subject to movement operations. For instance, in (6) we see that in Spanish the dislocated phrase in CLLD cannot be construed with an epithet, while this is possible in HTLD, cf. (3):

(6)
a. A sus amigos Pedro los invitó a cenar.
acc his friends Pedro cl-acc invited-3sg to dine
‘As for his friends, Pedro invited them to dinner.’
b. *A sus amigos Pedro invitó a cenar esos idiotas.
acc his friends Pedro invited to dine these idiots
‘As for his friends, Pedro invited these idiots to dinner.’

On the other hand, resumption via an epithet phrase is possible in other languages, e.g., Lebanese Arabic (Aoun and Choueiri 2000). As shown in (8), the dislocated phrase can appear embedded under a verb like ‘to doubt’, hence it is CLLD-ed and not HTLD-ed (see section 3.2):

(7)

‘This suspect, you know that this idiot was imprisoned.’

‘I doubt that my sister Sami knows whether this idiot passed the exam.’

Epithets can be used as resumptive elements and can be interpreted as bound variables in certain contexts, as they are pronominal in nature. Jackendoff (1972), Lasnik (1976), Hornstein and Weinberg (1990) claim that the epithet phrases are inherently pronominal. On the other hand, Aoun and Choueiri (2000) claim that epithet phrases are similar to pronominals only when those occur with the pronominal morpheme in, e.g., Lebanese Arabic.
A second issue concerns the position of the pronominal. It appears to move in CLLD and CLD, but not in HTLD. The movement arguably is to Spec,CP for CLD, while in CLLD the clitic adjoins to a verb.

A further difference between the various types of LD concerns the base generation vs. movement of the LD-ed element in sentence initial position. The most significant asymmetry between HTLD and CLD/CLLD is that the latter two constructions show certain forms of ‘connectivity’ between the LD-ed phrase and the sentence internal position (whether this is bound or not by a clitic) which are entirely absent in HTLD (see Van Riemsdijk and Zwarts 1974; Cinque 1990c; Van Haaften et al. 1983, among others). Thus CLLD and CLD contrast with HTLD in that these two can be treated as movement constructions with respect to connectivity criteria, while HTLD cannot. 2
The connectivity phenomena that are absent from HTLD but do occur with CLD/CLLD can be summarized as follows (and see the contributions in Anagnostopoulou et al. 1997):

li.p: Idiom chunks are found in LD-ed position in CLLD and CLD but not in HTLD.
Bound pronouns can occur embedded in a larger LD-ed constituent in CLLD and CLD but not in HTLD.
Bound pronominal variables can occur within a LD-ed constituent in CLLD and CLD but not in HTLD.
Case connectivity is obligatory in CLLD and CLD but not in HTLD.

subsection.p: In section 3, I discuss the differences between HTLD and CLLD. In section 4, I pay particular attention to the issues of debate concerning the proper characterization of CLLD. In section 5, I turn to the differences between CLLD and CLD.

subsection.heading: 3.1 Differences between the two constructions
subsection.p: That HTLD and CLLD are two distinct constructions becomes apparent if we consider their basic properties (see Cinque 1990c; Dobrovie-Sorin 1990; Anagnostopoulou 1997; and others).

(i) First of all, there is a sharp intonational break between the LDed XP in HTLD and the rest of the sentence; such pause is not present in CLLD. Although the LD-ed phrase in CLLD is separated from the clause that follows it via a comma, the intonational break between the two is much weaker than that present with HTLD.
(ii) The LD-ed phrase in CLLD can be any maximal phrase, as is illustrated in (9a) and (9b) with Italian examples. This contrasts with HTLD which allows only for LD-ed NPs.

(9)
a. Al mare ci siamo già stati.
to the seaside there have-1pl already been
‘To the seaside, there we have already been.’
b. Bella non lo é mai stata.
beautiful not it is ever been-3sg.fem
‘Beautiful, she has never been.’
(10) *To John I have already spoken to him.
(iii) The LD-ed element in CLLD can occur in front of any subordinate type, as the Italian sentence in (11) suggests:

(11)
L’ unica person che a Gianni non gli ha mia fatto un favore.
the only person which to John not him has ever done a favor
‘The only person which to John not to him has ever done a favor.’
HTLD typically occurs in root contexts, as the ungrammaticality of the Spanish example in (12) indicates:

(12)
*Sin embargo estoy segure que Bernardo nadei confia en ese idiota.
without embargo am sure that Bernardo nobody confides to this idiot
‘On the other hand, I am sure that, Bernardo, nobody has confidence in this idiot.’

(iv) In CLLD there is no theoretical limit to the number of the LD-ed phrases. HTLD allows no more than one LD-ed phrase. This is evident in the contrast between the Italian and English sentences shown in (13):

(13)
a. Di vestiti a me Gianni in quel negozio non mi ce ne ha mai comprati.
clothes to me Gianni in that shop not to me there of them has ever bought
‘As for clothes, for me, Gianni has never bought them in that shop.’
b. *Mary John she likes him.

(v) In languages like Spanish and Greek, the IP internal resumptive element in CLLD, if present, can be a clitic pronoun only. No such requirement holds of HTLD. In fact in HTLD the resumptive element can be a clitic-doubled pronoun or an epithet, as the Greek examples in (14–15) show:

(14)
Ton Petro ton nostalgo poli.
the Peter-acc him mis-1sg much
‘Peter, I miss him much.’

(15)
O Petros ton nostalgo ton gliko mu/afto poli.
The Peter-nom him miss him sweet my/this much
‘As for Peter, I miss my sweety/this guy much.’
On the other hand, in Lebanese Arabic CLLD the resumptive element can be an epithet, cf. (8).

(vi) In CLLD there is obligatory connectivity between the LD-ed phrase and IP internal position. There is no such connectivity in HTLD. One such case is Connectivity with respect to Binding Theory, as is clear in the following Italian examples, where the distribution of the reflexive and personal pronoun correlates with their distribution in non LD-ed positions, i.e., base positions:

(16)
A lei/*a se stessa Maria dice che non ci pensiamo mai.
of her/of herself Mary says that not there we think ever
‘Mary says that we never think about her.’

(17)
A *lei/a se stessa Maria non ci pensia.
of her/of herself Mary not there she think
‘Mary does not think about herself.’

Another case of connectivity is with respect to Case in languages exhibiting case morphology such as Greek. In HTLD there is no obligatory case agreement between the LD-ed phrase and the nominal expression clause internally. CLLD, on the other hand, forces case agreement. In (18a), the HTLD-ed element bears nominative Case, while the Case borne by the clitic clause internally is accusative, i.e., the Case of the LD-ed element in HTLD and the Case of the clitic clause internally do not need to match. On the other hand in (18b), an embedded clause where only CLLD is possible, case matching is obligatory, i.e., both the LD-ed phrase and the clitic must bear accusative: 3

(18)
a. I Maria tin ematha kala tosa hronia.
the Mary her learnt well so many years
‘As for Mary, I know her after so many years.’
b. Ipe oti ti Maria/*i Maria tin emathe kala tosa hronia.
said that the Mary-acc/*nom her learnt well so many years
‘He said that as for Mary, he knows her well after so many years.’
Furthermore, LD-ed idiom chunks are ill formed in HTLD but can be well formed in CLLD:

(19)
a. *I tihi tu kathe ftohos tin ekane pigenodas stin Ameriki.
the luck-nom his every poor her did going to America
b. Tin tihi tu kathe ftohos tin ekane pigenodas stin Ameriki.
the luck-acc his every poor her did going to America
‘Every poor person made his luck by going to America.’

(vii) A further and crucial difference between CLLD and HTLD is that only CLLD is subject to locality constraints. The fact that the relation between the LD-ed element and the resumptive pronoun in CLLD is sensitive to islands (cf. (20b), and see the discussion in section 4.3), while this is not the case in HTLD seems to suggest that CLLD is derived by a type of wh-movement. As the contrast in (20) shows, HTLD is not sensitive to a relative clause island, while CLLD is:

(20)
a. I Maria htes gnorisa ton andra pu tin pandreftike.
the Mary-nom yesterday met the man that her married
‘As for Mary, I met yesterday the man that married her.’
b. *Tin Maria htes gnorisa ton andra pu tin pandreftike.
the Mary-acc yesterday met the man that her married

While it is uncontroversial that HTLD involves base generation of the LD-ed phrase in sentence initial position, whether or not CLLD displays actual movement of the LD-ed phrase remains a matter of controversy, since CLLD does not behave like wh-movement in all respects. On the one hand, Cinque (1977), Dobrovie-Sorin (1990), Mahajan (1990), Sportiche (1996b) and Kayne (1994) claim that there is actual movement in CLLD. On the other hand, Cinque (1990c), Iatridou (1994), and Anagnostopoulou (1994) among others claim that that there is no such movement involved. In the next section I present the structural analysis of HTLD and CLLD and in section 4 I come to the arguments in favor of and against the movement vs. base generation analysis for CLLD.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Syntactic analysis of HTLD and CLLD
subsection.p: Generally, HTLD elements are represented as being CP adjuncts (21a), while CLLD elements are considered by some researchers to be IP adjuncts (21b) while others analyze them as CP adjuncts, the resumptive element being contained within IP in both cases: 4

The main argument for analyzing HTLD-ed elements as CP adjuncts comes from the observation that these phrases occur only in root contexts. The main argument for analyzing CLLD-ed elements as IP adjuncts relies on the fact that these phrases occur in all types of embedded contexts and not only in so-called CP-recursion (Iatridou and Kroch 1992) environments. This is illustrated below with an example containing an adverbial adjunct from Greek:

(22)
I Maria ine harumeni tora pu ton Jani ton paratise.
the Mary is happy now that the John him left
‘Mary is happy now that she has left John.’

In order to understand the line of argumentation it is necessary to briefly discuss CP-recursion here. The phenomenon of CP-recursion is discussed most prominently on the basis of Germanic data. In certain embedded contexts as shown in (23a) with a Frisian example (from Iatridou and Kroch 1992: 4) verb second order can occur, while in others (23b, c), only the verb final order is allowed (see chapter 23):

(23)
a. Pyt sei dat hy hie my sjoen.
Pyt said that he had me seen
‘Pyt said that he had seen me.’
b. Pyt betreueret dat er my sjoen hie.
Pyt regrets that he me seen had
‘Pyt regrets that he had seen me.’
c. *Pyt betreueret dat er my hie sjoen.

According to de Haan and Weerman (1986), CP-recursion occurs in just those environments and with just those verbs that allow deletion of the overt complementizer. Iatridou and Kroch claim that this restriction suggests that CP-recursion occurs only when the embedded clause is governed by a local L-marking head. As expected, clauses not governed by a lexical head (adjunct clauses (24) and sentential subjects) do not allow embedded V2:

(24)
*Ik sil fuortgean at jo wolle dizze film net sjen.
I will leave if you want this film not see

Crucially, CP-recursion is possible under specific conditions, namely it occurs only when the embedded clause is selected by a certain kind of verb. These verbs are referred to as ‘bridge’ verbs in the literature, e.g., verbs like say, whisper, etc. The Greek example in (22) does not contain a CP-recursion environment, since it exemplifies an adverbial clause. Thus it is difficult to maintain the CP adjunction hypothesis, as the LD-ed phrase in (22) follows the complementizer pu and no second C position is contained in the clause.

It should be pointed out here that Rizzi (1997) associates CLLD phrases with special projections in the CP domain, which is now split into a number of specified projections such as FocusPhrase and TopicPhrase (25). LD-ed elements occupy Topic Phrases. Current research investigates whether these Topic projections have different properties.
(25) [ForceP [TopicP [FocusP [TopicP [FinP]]]]]

subsection.heading: 4 CLLD: movement vs. base generation
subsection.p: At first sight the properties of CLLD seem to suggest that this construction differs from HTLD precisely in involving movement. 5,6 However, matters are not that simple. There are two related considerations. First, CLLD does not behave like wh-movement in all respects, as will be discussed below in section 4.2. Second, one important issue a movement analysis for CLLD has to address is the co-occurrence of movement with a clitic pronoun that matches in features the putatively moved phrases. Essentially two possibilities suggest themselves. The first consists in regarding the construction as an instantiation of the clitic-doubling phenomenon. The second consists in regarding the clitic pronoun as an overt spelling out of the pronominal features left on the (wh-) trace. As Cinque and others point out, neither proposal is without problems.

In what follows I first discuss certain problems with the view that CLLD is derived via movement through a clitic-doubling input construction and I then turn to arguments for the non-wh-movement nature of CLLD.

subsection.heading: 4.1 CLLD and clitic doubling
subsection.p: Clitic doubling is a common construction in many languages, such as Romanian, dialects of Spanish, Lebanese Arabic and Greek, in which a clitic agreeing in features with the object appears along with the object (see chapter 14). This is illustrated in (26) with an example from Greek:

(26)
To agorasa to vivlio tu Jani.
it bought the book-acc the John-gen
‘I bought John's book.’

In the languages that have clitic doubling the issue therefore arises whether this construction is the source for CLLD which is derived by movement of the doubled element to the sentence initial position, as shown in (27):
(27) [DP to vivlio]i to agorasa ti
However, there are certain problems with the view that clitic doubling is the source for CLLD.

First, as Cinque (1990c) points out there are languages that have CLLD (28a), but do not have clitic doubling (28b). One such a language is Italian. Hence for these languages a clitic-doubling input structure could not be assumed:

(28)
a. *Lo conosciamo Gianni.
him know-1pl Gianni
b. Gianni lo conosciamo.
Gianni him know-1pl
Second, there are languages in which doubling is subject to Kayne's Generalization while CLLD is not. Rio Platese Spanish presents such a case:

(29)
Lo vimos a Juan. Rio Platese Spanish
Him saw-we a Juan
‘We saw Juan.’

(30)
Lo vimos Juan.
him saw-we Juan
‘We saw Juan yesterday.’

Third, while the cases of doubling reported in the literature are limited to (doubling of) DPs, the dislocated constituent in CLLD can be any maximal phrase. The Italian data in (31) (Cinque 1990c: 58) exemplify CLLD of PPs and APs:

(31)
a. A casa, non ci sono stato ancora. Italian
To home, not there am been yet
‘I haven't been home yet.’
b. Di questa faccenda, non ne voglio più parlare.
Of this matter, not of-it want anymore talk
‘I don't want to talk about this matter anymore.’
c. Bella, pare che non lo sia mai stata.
Beautiful, seems that not it is ever been
‘It doesn't seem that she has ever been beautiful.’

Forth, there are semantic classes of NPs that appear in CLLD structures but cannot be clitic doubled. As the Greek examples in (32) show, while CLLD of numeral noun phrases is allowed, clitic doubling is not (see Iatridou 1994):

(32)
a. Tria provlimata mono o Kostas ta elise.
three problems only the Kostas them solved
‘Only Kostas solved three problems.’
b. *Mono o Kostas ta elise tria provlimata.
only the Kostas them solved three problems

Finally, there are languages that have an animacy requirement on clitic doubling, such as Spanish (see Torrego 1998 for a recent discussion and references therein), but not on CLLD. As the contrast in (33) shows, while clitic doubling is sensitive to the [+/−animate] nature of the doubled NP (i.e., doubling of [−animate] DPs is ungrammatical), this is not the case with CLLD, where [−animate] DPs can occupy sentence initial positions:

(33)
a. Lo vimos a Juan.
him saw to Juan
‘We saw Juan.’
b. *Lo vimos el/al libro.
it saw the/to the book
c. El libro lo compramos ayer.
the book it bought yesterday
‘As for the book, we bought it yesterday.’

These differences are unexpected if CLLD is the movement counterpart of doubling, arguing against the reduction of CLLD to an underlying clitic-doubling source. For this reason, Cinque (1990c), Iatridou (1994) and Anagnostopoulou (1994) propose that in CLLD the LD-ed phrase is base generated in a left peripheral adjunct position. The main problem for base-generation analyses of CLLD is that they have to appeal to special mechanisms in order to derive the connectivity property of CLLD (for selective island sensitivity, see Demirdache 1991 and Iatridou 1994). In section 4.3, I come back to this issue.

In particular, Iatridou proposes that CLLD is a predication structure: the LD-ed DP is the subject of predication and it is base generated in a position adjoined to the clause which forms the complex predicate; the open position necessary for the clause to function as a variable is provided by the cl-pro chain:
(34) [CP/IP XPLD-ed [CP/IP cl pro]]

subsection.heading: 4.2 CLLD and its (non-)wh-movement nature
subsection.p: I highlight some differences between CLLD and constructions involving object fronting as the result of focus/wh-movement (see chapter 26). 7 Here I compare OVS/OSV orders with OclS/ OScl-V orders, that is constructions where the object appears in a peripheral position and is not resumed by a clitic clause internally to constructions where a resumptive clitic is present.

First of all, there are interpretational and intonational differences. In CLLD the fronted object constitutes old information and cannot be stressed. In OSV, where the object is fronted as a result of movement, the object is new information and receives focal stress. This is illustrated below with an Italian example:

(35)
a. Il tuo libro lo ha comprato.
the your book it have bought
‘As for your book, I have bought it.’
b. IL TUO LIBRO – ho comprato.
the your book
have bought

There are further differences between CLLD and focus movement. As (35) shows, in CLLD there is a clitic present within the clause. On the other hand, a focalized element is incompatible with a resumptive clitic (see Cinque 1990c; Tsimpli 1995; Rizzi 1997). Moreover, a CLLD-ed element never gives rise to Weak Crossover effects (WCO). Such effects are, however, detectable with focus:

(36)
a. Gianni sua madre lo ha sempre apprezzato.
Gianni his mother him has always appreciated
‘As for Gianni, his mother has always appreciated him.’
b. ??GIANNI sua madre – ha sempre apprezzato.
Gianni his mother – has always appreciated
The fact that no WCO violation occurs in (36a) indicates that the postverbal empty category is not a variable. 8

It has been suggested that such behavior with respect to WCO leads to a distinction between two types of A′-binding. Specifically, Lasnik and Stowell (1991) assume that WCO is a distinctive characteristic of A′-relations involving genuine quantification. Thus, A′-dependencies must be split into those involving a quantifier that binds a variable, and those that involve non-quantificational A′-binding, but rather binding of a null constant (nc) (see Rizzi 1997):

(37)
a. *Who does his mother like t (vbl)
b. John who his mother like (nc)

Assuming WCO to be a diagnostic of what constitutes a quantifier–variable binding relation leads us to conclude that Focus involves quantificational A′ binding, while CLLD does not (see Rizzi 1997). According to Rizzi, if Focus is quantificational and CLLD is not, then the difference exemplified in (36) follows as well. In (36b) the focalized element must bind a syntactic variable, hence a clitic cannot be present, since the clitic is an overt pronominal head, its trace is an X0 trace. So the example with a clitic would be ruled out by the Principle of Full Interpretation which requires that quantifiers bind variables.

Another difference between the two constructions concerns the type of elements that can/cannot appear in CLLD. In Italian, bare quantificational elements cannot appear in CLLD constructions, while they easily allow focalization:

(38)
a. *Nessuno lo ho visto.
nobody him have seen
b. NESSUNO – ho visto.
Moreover, a clause can contain several CLLD elements but only one focus, hence the ungrammaticality of (39):

(39)
*A GIANNI IL LIBRO darò.
to Gianni the book I will give

Similar effects are observed when we compare CLLD to wh-movement. According to Cinque (1990c), if CLLD involved wh-movement, then the object clitic that appears in this constructions must be either the spell-out of a wh-trace or an instance of clitic doubling. Assuming for the moment that the first option cannot be maintained for the reasons discussed above, let us consider the second one. First, note that the clitic in CLLD does not seem to behave like a wh-trace, given that licensing of parasitic gaps is not permitted. Hence it does not have the properties of a variable.

(40)
*Gianni l’ho cercate per mesi senza trovare e.
Gianni I have him looked for for months without finding

With respect to the licensing of parasitic gap constructions, Demirdache (1991) points out that the reason for the ungrammaticality of the example in (40) is that the trace is indirectly bound by the pronoun. She assumes Haik's convention on variable binding ((i) a trace must be locally A′-bound, (ii) a pronoun must be A′-bound). This condition allows the index of any variable to percolate to the maximal projection immediately dominating it. The idea is the following: a pronoun need not be locally A′-bound, a trace, however, must be locally A′-bound. This predicts that when the pronoun is to the right of the parasitic gap the parasitic gap is licensed. Such is the case in Greek (see also next section):

(41)
a. To Jani i Maria ipe horis na agapa oti tha ton pandrefti.
the John the Mary said without subj love that fut him marry
‘As for John, Mary said, without loving him, that she will marry him.’
b. *To Jani i Maria ipe oti tha ton pandrefti horis na agapa.
the John the Mary said that fut him marry without subj love
Second, the clitic that occurs in CLLD does not occur in ordinary wh-constructions, as is shown in (42):

(42)
Chi (*lo) hai visto.
whom him you have seen

According to Cinque, a wh-operator is incompatible with a clitic, due to the quantificational nature of the wh-phrase. This is supported by an asymmetry between quantified NPs and bare quantifiers with respect to CLLD in Italian. As discussed in Cinque (1990c: 15), CLLD of bare quantifiers in Italian does not require a resumptive clitic:

(43)
Qualcuno (lo) troveremo.
someone him we will find
‘Someone, we will find him.’
When the clitic is present the quantifier is interpreted as specific, when the clitic is absent the quantifier is interpreted as non-specific (see also Dobrovie-Sorin 1990 for Romanian).

However, according to Demirdache (1991), this difference could be made to follow from the difference of the level of representation at which movement takes place. While wh- and focus movement take place in the syntax, CLLD involves LF movement of an operator.

Third, under the assumption that wh-movement is constrained by Subjacency as re-formulated in Chomsky (1986a), then CLLD does not involve wh-movement. There appear to be perfectly grammatical CLLD structures that Subjacency would exclude, if they were derived by wh-movement:

(44)
a. Loro il libro credo che a Carlo sia siguro che non glielo daranno mai.
they the book believe that to Carlo is certain that not him-it will give ever
‘It is certain that they will never give the book to Carlo.’
b. *A cui non so quando si saprà cosa daranno.
to whom not know when one will know what they will give

In (44) three different constituents are LD-ed from the most deeply embedded clause. Whatever derivation is chosen a violation of Subjacency will ensue, as is the case with wh-movement in (44). See Cinque (1990c: 63ff. for details).

Another property suggesting that CLLD does not involve wh-movement is that, unlike ordinary wh-constructions, it apparently cannot avail itself of successive cyclic derivations. If we consider adjuncts, which have to move through any intermediate Spec,CP (see chapter 64), we detect a clear contrast between ordinary wh-movement constructions and CLLD. Consider the Italian examples below:

(45)
PER QUESTA RAGIONE ha detto che se ne andrà.
for this reason has said that will leave
‘For this reason, he said that he will leave.’

(46)
Per quale ragione ha detto che se ne andrà?
for which reason has said that will leave
‘For which reason did he say that he will leave?’

(47)
*Per questa ragione ha detto che se ne andrà.
for this reason has said that will leave

(45), a sentence involving focus, and (46), a wh-question, are grammatical, but the corresponding example involving CLLD in (47) is not. If CLLD does not involve any form of movement, the contrast directly follows.

The above facts then seem to suggest that CLLD is not immediately compatible with a movement analysis. However, in the literature arguments have been presented, see e.g. Demirdache (1991), Iatridou (1994) and Aoun and Benmamoun (1998), which seem to suggest that CLLD or at least certain types of CLLD do involve wh-movement. We will discuss their arguments in the next section.

subsection.heading: 4.3 CLLD and island effects
subsection.p: As mentioned above, according to Cinque, the relation between the LD-ed element in CLLD and the clitic is not one of movement. As the following Lebanese Arabic data show, the relation between the CLLD-ed NP and the clitic can violate islands, such as the Adjunct Condition, and the Complex NP constraint (see Aoun and Benmamoun 1998: 571):

(48)
a. Sm
t
nno Naadya r
ht m
n duun ma t
hke ma
-a.
heard that Nadia left-2sm without comp talking with her
‘I heard that Nadia, you left without talking to her.’
b. Sm
t
nno ha-l-kteeb hkiit m
l-walad yalli katab
al-ee.
heard that this the book talked-2sm with the boy who wrote on it
‘I heard that this book, you talked with the boy who wrote on it.’
This is expected under a base-generated approach to CLLD, since movement obeys strong (and weak) islands.

However, as has been mentioned earlier on, CLLD in some languages, such as Italian, Hebrew and Greek, is constrained by islands. This is illustrated below with Greek examples containing a relative and an adjunct clause respectively (taken from Iatridou 1994):

(49)
a. *Ton Kosta sinandisa tin kopela pu ton ide.
the Kostas met-1sg the girl that him saw-3
b. *Tin efimerida apokimithike diavazondas tin.
the paper fell-3sg asleep reading it

Note, however, that in the languages in which CLLD is constrained by islands it displays selective island sensitivity in the sense that long distance CLLD freely violates weak islands, illustrated below with a wh-island:

(50)
To forema den ksero pu na to valo.
the dress neg know where subjt it put
‘As for the dress I do not know where to put it.’
In other words, CLLD is sensitive to strong islands, but not to weak islands.

This is paradoxical under the base-generated approach: if islands constrain movement and not base-generated relations, why is the relationship between the clitic and the CLLD-ed element constrained by certain types of islands? Cinque (1990c) proposes as a solution that islands in fact do not distinguish movement from base-generated representations. Specifically, Cinque argues that connectivity and selective island sensitivity are properties of chains, regardless of the origin of these chains, i.e., whether they are created via movement or not. In fact Cinque uses CLLD in order to argue in favor of his notion of ‘Binding Chain’, i.e., a chain which is defined in terms of referential indices (Rizzi 1990b) and can hold at an arbitrary distance, in the sense that it shows insensitivity to Relativized Minimality Effects. For a phrase to enter a binding relation with its trace, it must not only occupy an A′-position and receive a referential theta-role, but also it must have intrinsic referential properties, properties that allow it, for example, to be D-linked in Pesetsky's (1987b) terms. What is crucial for Cinque is that sensitivity to strong islands is a property that characterizes chains regardless of whether they involve movement or base generation. In other words Binding is sensitive to strong barriers only. Hence strong islands, which are properties of chains, constrain the chain between binding relations between the LD-ed element and the operator variable chain created by the clitic. On the other hand, weak islands (wh-islands, inner islands, factive islands) constrain movement. Hence CLLD is not sensitive to conditions that directly affect movement.

On the other hand, Iatridou (1994) and Demirdache (1991) have tried to show that the island sensitivity problem is only apparent, because CLLD does involve some movement after all. 9 Specifically, Iatridou (1994) argues that the LD-ed element in CLLD is generated as an adjunct to the lower CP, the one containing the clitic, from which it moves to the higher clause, hence CLLD involves some type of movement. If this is correct, it should be possible to test such a movement. One such test involves parasitic gaps, as mentioned in the previous section. If the alleged movement crosses an adjunct containing a parasitic gap, then the acceptability of that sentence would confirm the existence of such a movement. This movement forms an A′/A′ chain which licenses the parasitic gap, and is in fact acceptable in Greek. (51) is compared with (52) which has the parasitic gap in a position not crossed by the movement out of the LD-position. This sentence is ungrammatical:

(51)
To Janii
i Maria ipe horis na agapa ti
oti tha ton pandrefti.
the John the Mary said without subj love that fut him marry
‘As for John, Mary said, without loving him, that she will marry him.’

(52)
*To Jani i
i Maria ipe ti oti tha ton pandrefti horis na agapa.
the John the Mary said that fut him marry without subj love

It has also been pointed out in the literature that a language can have both a type of CLLD formed by base generation and a type of CLLD formed via movement. For instance, Aoun and Benmamoun distinguish between two types of CLLD in Lebanese Arabic. Type 1 is base generated and hence freely violates islands. Type 2, on the other hand, is generated via movement and hence shows a different behavior. In particular Aoun and Benmamoun show that CLLD does not exhibit a uniform behavior with respect to this interaction: wh-movement and topicalization across a CLLD-ed NP related to a clitic within an island is consistently ruled out. However, wh-movement and topicalization across a CLLD-ed NP which is not separated from its clitic by an island is possible. This is schematically represented in (53):

(53)
a. [WH/Top) Np/PP]j CLLD-edNPi V+clitici tj
b. *[WH/Top) Np/PP]j CLLD-edNPi [island clitici] tj

They argue that the former construction (53a) is a result of movement. If this is so, it is expected that in this language only the former construction would show reconstruction effects (see chapter 54). This seems to be borne out. Consider the following sentences:

(54)
a. T
lmiiz-a
itaan bt
rfo
nno k
ll m
allme
aasas
t-o.
student-her the naughty know-2 that every teacher punished him
‘Her naughty student, you know that every teacher punished him.’
b. *T
lmiiz-a
itaan fallaytp
alblma k
ll m
allme
aasas
t-o.
student-her the naughty left-2 before every teacher punished him
‘Her student, you left before every teacher punished him.’

In (54a) the pronoun within the CLLD-ed NP can be interpreted as bound by the quantifier phrase ‘every teacher’. Bound pronouns must be c-commanded at LF by the elements that bind. The relevant bound reading follows the assumption that the CLLD-ed NP reconstructs under the subject QP. In (54b), on the other hand, no reconstruction takes place since the CLLD-ed NP is base generated in its position. Aoun and Benmamoun account for the interception effects observed in (54) as follows: a moved CLLD-ed NP reconstructs and therefore does not intercept wh-movement. A base-generated CLLD-ed NP cannot reconstruct and therefore does not intercept wh-movement. 10

Anagnostopoulou (1994) shows that there are in fact two types of reconstruction effects: full reconstruction effects which presuppose movement, and partial reconstruction effects which do not presuppose movement. As she points out, CLLD in Greek does not exhibit full reconstruction effects. Consider the examples in (55):

(55)
a. *O Janis tisi
epestrepse to vivlio tis Mariasi.
the John her returned the book-acc the Mary-gen
b. *TO VIVLIO TIS MARIASi
tisi
epestrepse o Janis.
the book the Mary her returned the John
c. To vivlio tis Mariasi
o Janis tisi
to epestrepse.
the book the Mary the John her it returned

In (55a) the indirect object is co-indexed with the possessive genitive inside the direct object phrase. Under this interpretation the sentence is ruled out as a Condition C violation. (55b) is also bad. Under the assumption that focus fronting involves actual movement of the XP, the status then of (55a) and (55b) is identical. On the other hand, (55c) is acceptable. The genitive contained within the CLLD-ed direct object can be coreferential with the indirect object clitic IP-internally. There is no Condition C effect in CLLD which does not involve actual movement. 11 Anagnostopoulou further argues that connectivity characterizes CLLD because of the existence of a chain which permits transmission of features relevant for Binding Theory.

subsection.heading: 4.4 Movement approaches to CLLD
subsection.p: In this section I come to discuss analyses that favor a movement approach to the CLLD derived from a clitic-doubling input structure. Agouraki (1993), Kayne (1994), Sportiche (1996b), and Grohmann (2000a), among others, argue in favor of analyses along these lines, which straightforwardly explain the connectedness properties of CLLD.

Before I present such analyses, it is necessary to address one of the arguments against this view, namely the fact that languages such as French lack clitic doubling, but do have CLLD. French has right dislocation, a construction that is superficially similar to clitic doubling. If the movement analysis for CLLD were on the right track, the result would be that the distinction between clitic doubling and right dislocation can no longer be stated.
Right dislocation is a construction in which a clitic co-occurs with a phrase to its right as illustrated in (11) with an example from French (see chapter 14):

(56)
Je l’ ai vu, l’ assassin. French
I him have seen, the murderer
‘I saw him, the murderer.’ (Jaeggli 1986b: 33)

Clitic doubling and right dislocation are subject to different constraints. For instance, in right dislocation, the dislocated phrase is set off from the rest of the sentence with a sharp intonational break, as illustrated in (57), while no such break is required before the object in clitic doubling, as illustrated in (58):

(57)
Parece que tuvieron que llevarla de urgencia a los Estados Unidos la hija de Coronel Martínez. Rio Platese Spanish
‘It seems that they had to take her urgently to the United States the daughter of Coronel Martinez.’

(58)
Parece que tuvieron que llevarla a la hija de Coronel Martinez de urgencia a los Estados Unidos.
‘It seems that they had to take her the daughter of Coronel Martinez urgently to the United States.’

In languages such as Greek in which clitic doubling is restricted to certain types of DPs, it is possible for a DO clitic to co-occur with an indefinite in CLLD and right dislocation, but not in clitic doubling:

(59)
To pino pu ke pu ena uzaki.
it drink now and then a glass of ouzo
‘I drink a glass of ouzo every now and then.’

Kayne (1994) and Zubizarreta (1998) relate right dislocation to CLLD. Kayne (1994: 82–3) proposes that in both clitic doubling and right dislocation, the DP doubled by the clitic is base generated in an argument position, thus unifying structurally clitic doubling with right dislocation. These authors have argued that clitic doubling, right dislocation, and CLLD have the same underlying structure with a clitic doubling a DP in all three constructions. The doubled DP starts out as a complement of the verb as in (60), and is never generated in a left or right peripheral position. The clitic could be analyzed as the head of a determiner phrase, in whose specifier the LD-ed phrase is originally generated (Torrego 1998).
(60) [CP DPLD-edi [IP clV ti]]

To express the intonational and interpretational differences between right dislocation and doubling, Kayne suggests that the former construction is an instance of CLLD at LF, i.e., the right dislocated phrase undergoes LF-movement of the CLLD type. Covert CLLD is triggered by a feature having the effect of a particular intonation contour at PF. No such feature is present in clitic doubling. On the other side, Zubizarreta (1998: 198, n. 57) suggests that right dislocation involves clitic left dislocation followed by leftward movement of the TP across the left dislocated constituent. Given the distributional differences between right dislocation and clitic doubling mentioned above, the latter approach is descriptively more adequate as it captures the fact that right dislocated elements occupy a peripheral position in the sentence, unlike doubled elements. In Kayne's proposal, this difference is not explained. See also Cecchetto (1996), and Agouraki (1993). 12
In the next section I turn to a brief discussion of the specificity associated with CLLD.

subsection.heading: 4.5 CLLD and specificity
subsection.p: Generally, since CLLD involves a topic phrase in the left periphery of the clause, the elements that may appear in this position are specific. However, there exists a cross-linguistic asymmetry with respect to LD of bare quantifiers. For instance, in Greek (Anagnostopoulou 1999b) bare quantifiers either undergo CLLD, in which case a clitic is required and the quantifiers are generally interpreted as specific, or they undergo focus-movement, in which case the clitic is necessarily absent (this is always the case with focus-movement in Greek, cf. Tsimpli 1995 for discussion and references):

(61)
a. Kapjon i Maria ton epiase na andigrafi.
someone the Mary him caught-3 subj cheat-3
‘Mary caught somebody cheating.’
b. *Kapjon tha vrume alla den kserume pjon.
someone fut find-1pl but neg know-1pl who-acc
c. KAPJON tha vrume alla den kserume pjon.
someone fut find-1pl but neg know-1pl who-acc
‘We will find someone but we do not know whom.’
Second, as Demirdache (1991) points out, measure phrases and idiom chunks which are non-referential can be connected to a clitic:

(62)
a. 70 chili non li pesa.
seventy kilos not them weigh
‘He does not weigh 70 kilos.’
b. Giustizia non la fara mai.
justice not her do ever
‘As for justice, he will never do it.’
Demirdache also observes that since any type of XP can be LD-ed why should a predicate, as in (63) below, be able to enter into a referential binding relation with a clitic?

(63)
Messo da parte non lo e mai stato.
got out of the way not it he ever was
Moreover, in languages such as Greek, the presence of a clitic is licit in wh-constructions, as exemplified in (64):

(64)
Pjon apo tus filus tu o Janis ton agapai perisotero.
who from the friends his the John him love-3 more
‘Who of his friends does John love more?’

The above data are discussed in Iatridou (1994) and Anagnostopoulou (1994). Both authors note that the presence of clitics is legitimate in wh-constructions in which the wh-phrase is D-linked (Pesetsky 1987b). Iatridou then argues that CLLD is in general only possible with D-linked DPs, a fact which explains why clitics are possible with D-linked interrogatives: these do not have the syntax of questions but rather they involve CLLD of a D-linked wh-phrase.
I now turn to a discussion of the similarities between CLLD and CLD.

subsection.heading: 5 CLLD and CLD
subsection.p: As mentioned in the introduction CLD is a typical Germanic construction which is characterized by the fact that the resumptive element inside the matrix clause is a demonstrative pronoun, which must be adjacent to the LD-ed element.

subsection.heading: 5.1 The common properties of CLLD and CLD
subsection.p: CLD and CLLD have a number of properties in common. 13 Investigation of these similarities led researchers to propose a uniform account of CLLD and CLD (see in particular Van Haaften et al. 1983; Demirdache 1991; Anagnostopoulou 1994, 1997; Wiltschko 1997b). The discussion below concentrates on data from Greek and Dutch:

li.p: In both constructions the left peripheral XP is understood as a topic.
Both have a gap in the argument position, while HTLD has a lexical pronoun in that position.
The left peripheral XP is an adjunct (see section 5.3 for details).
CLLD like CLD are unbounded, as (65) shows:

(65)
a. To Jani skeftika oti o Petros ipe oti ton ide.
the John thought that the Peter said that him saw
‘As for John, I thought that Peter said that he saw him.’
b. Jan die dacht ik dat Piet zei dat hij gezien had.
Jan that thought I that Piet said that he had seen
‘As for Jan, I thought that Piet said that he had seen him.’
Both constructions are sensitive to islands:

(66)
a. *Ti Maria htes gnorisa ton andra pu tin pandreftike.
the Mary yesterday met-1sg the man that her married
b. *Jan die vertelde Piet het verhaal dat hij verslagen had.
Jan that told Piet the story that he beated had
There is connectivity in both:

(67)
a. Ton eafto tu o Janis ton aporipti.
the self his the John him rejects
‘John rejects himself.’
b. Zichzelf daar praat Jan niet over.
himself there talks Jan not about

subsection.p: There are similar restrictions on the type of elements that may occur in the fronted position. It is standardly assumed that D-linking or referentiality are the most crucial factors involved. For example, bare quantifiers as in (68a) and (69a) are ungrammatical, while restricted QPs as in (68b) and (69b) are not:

(68)
a. *Kathena ton ksero.
everybody him know-1sg
b. Kathena ston kipo ton iksera.
everybody in the garden him knew-3sg

(69)
a. *Iedereen die ken ik. 14
everyone that know I
b. Iedereen in de tuin die kende ik.
everyone in the garden that knew I

subsection.heading: 5.2 The differences between CLLD and CLD
subsection.p: However, CLLD and CLD are by no means identical. In fact they display a number of differences, listed below:

li.p: In CLLD the resumptive pronoun is a clitic. In CLD the d-word can be stressed and can be replaced by a phrasal category. As Zwart (1993: 248), points out, the presence of the d-pronoun is not obligatory, while the presence of the clitic is obligatory:

(70)
Marie (die) kust Jan niet.
Mary that kisses John not
‘Mary, John doesn't kiss.’
Grohmann (2000a) suggests that when the d-pronoun is not present the construction is similar to focalization:

(71)
Jan die z’n ouders ken ik niet.
John that his parents know I not
‘John, I do not know his parents.’

In CLLD the clitic can be clause internal, whereas the d-word must be the first element after the LD-ed phrase. In root clauses, since Dutch requires V-to-C movement, the verb immediately follows the d-pronoun:

(72)
Ton Jani i Maria ton kseri.
the John the Mary him knows

(73)
*Jan die ik ken niet.
Jan that I know not
CLLD can involve stacking of LD-ed phrases. This is not possible in CLD:

(74)
*Jan op school die daar zag ik niet.
John at school that there saw I not
CLLD displays selective island sensitivity in the sense that long-distance CLLD freely violates wh-type islands (see section 4). CLD is sensitive to all islands:

(75)
*Jan die weet ik niet waarom Piet geloofde.
Jan that know I not why Piet believed
Finally, the LD-ed phrase in CLLD can occur at the front of any subordinate type clause. CLD basically occurs in root contexts:

(76)
*Ik denk dat Jan die ik niet ken.
I think that Jan that I not know

subsection.heading: 5.3 Deriving the similarities and the differences between CLD and CLLD
subsection.p: In the literature, it has been argued that the LD-ed phrase in CLD is a CP adjunct, and the d-pronoun is moved to Spec,CP from its base position, as illustrated in (77):
(77) [CP XPLD-ed [CP d-pronoun t]]

CLD has been analyzed by some researchers as involving raising of the LD-ed element to the sentence initial position, i.e. Spec,CP (see, e.g., Grohmann 2000a). 15 Wiltschko's (1997b) analysis also accepts that the LD-ed phrase in CLD is in CP, but proposes that it is parasitic on the syntactic operator chain between the topicalized pronoun and its trace.
Demirdache (1991) and Anagnostopoulou (1997) propose that CLD and CLLD can be unified, both involving the general schema in (78):
(78) [FP XPLD-ed [FP Operator t]]

According to Anagnostopoulou (1994, 1997), predication licenses both cases of (78). The d-pronoun and the clitic head a predicate variable chain, the LD-ed XP being the subject of predication. This approach captures the parallelism between two constructions in a straightforward manner. A clitic-doubling alternative to CLLD, on the other hand, seems to miss a generalization. The differences between these two construction types can be accounted for in terms of a difference in adjunction sites. Specifically, CP-adjunction is forced in CLD, but not in CLLD.

As discussed in section 3.2, embedded CLLD is free to apply everywhere, a fact which suggests that the LD-ed phrase in CLLD is adjoined to IP, contrary to what Demirdache (1991) and Iatridou (1994) have proposed. Recall that Iatridou and Kroch (1992) have argued that the phenomenon of CP-recursion is possible under CPs that are selected by a bridge verb. If the correct analysis of embedded CLLD is in terms of CP-recursion, then Iatridou and Kroch's analysis is not compatible with it, as the conditions on CP-recursion are systematically violated in the case of embedded CLLD. Hence a more correct analysis seems to be one in which the LD-ed phrase is adjoined to IP. On this view, the differences between CLD and CLLD can be captured if one assumes that CLD requires a matrix CP. 16

Haegeman (2001), on the other hand, adopts Rizzi's analysis of the split CP and assumes that in Dutch root clauses the finite verb occupies Fin. She assumes that a fronted topicalized constituent occupies the specifier of TopP and that the doubling die pronoun occupies the specifier of FinP. When the pronoun is absent, it is assumed that a non-overt analogue occupies the specifier of TopP. This non-overt analogue is taken to be a null operator, OP:

A further refinement needs to be added here. In V2 languages such as Dutch, fronted objects receive either topic interpretation (‘old information’) or focal interpretation (‘new information’), in which case they will have focal stress. One may assume that when fronted constituents receive topic interpretation the structure is as in (79) above, with an overt or non-overt topic operator. When focal, Haegeman assumes that the structure is as in (80) with the fronted constituent moved to Foc and the verb moves to Foc:

subsection.heading: 6 CLLD in the noun phrase
subsection.p: Within noun phrases, there exists a construction in which both a possessive pronoun and a possessor DP are present. This pattern is found in many languages. (81) provides a non-exhaustive list of examples (Haegeman 2001; Alexiadou et al., forthcoming):

(81)
a. Per sin bil Norwegian
Peter his car
b. ae mand hans hus W. Jutlandic
a man his house
c. dem Vater seine Katze German
the father his cat
d. em bueb zini Mutter Swiss German
a child his mother
e. Peter z’n Kat Dutch
Peter his cat
f. Marie eur katte W. Flemish
Mary her cat
g. Epkema syn plan Frisian
Epkema his plan
h. the Man of Lawe his Tale Middle English
i. li serf sum pedre Old French
the serf his fater
j. Jón hin-ós Krio
John his house
k. Peter sua filho Malayo-Portuguese
Peter his son

The particular instantiation of the construction is not homogeneous cross-linguistically. For instance, in languages with overt morphological case the possessor DP may be associated with different case-forms. In German (81c), the possessor DP dem Vater appears in the dative case. The Swiss German possessor em bueb in (81d) is a ‘nominative pendens’; both in German and in Middle English the doubled construction occurs with a dative possessor, but it may also occur with a genitive possessor. The genitive possessor is illustrated in (82a) for German and in (82b) for English. Middle Dutch doubled possessors occur in the genitive case, illustrated in (82c):

(82)
a. bringt ja des teufels sein Gepäck.
bring ja the devil-gen his pack
b. God Mars’es his vigour Sir Robert's his shape
c. alle des conincks sijn landen
all the king-gen his lands
Corver (1990) argues at length that in (81e) above z’n occupies the same position as genitive ‘s, i.e., D0. That this is so is suggested by the fact that they are mutually exclusive:

(83)
a. Jans auto
Jan's car
b. Jan z’n auto
Jan his car
c. *Jans z’n auto
Corver further suggests that this possessor is actually generated in Spec,DP. Note that the possessor in Spec,DP is not assigned case from outside its clause:

(84)
a. Ich habe dem Mann seinen Wagen gesehen.
I have the man-dat his car seen
b. Dem Mann sein Wagen wurde gestohlen.
the man-dat his car was stolen

In (84) the possessor bears dative case, i.e., an oblique case form. It is not assigned structural case from outside. However, the DP containing the possessor is assigned case by a governing case-assigner, the verb and Infl.

It is a characteristic property of this construction that it only occurs with third person pronouns. First and second person pronouns, on the other hand, are unacceptable, as can be seen in the following Dutch (85a) and German (85b) examples:

(85)
a. *mij m’n moeder
my my mother
b. *euch Brüdern euer Haus
your Brothers-dat your house
This restriction to the third person is not exclusive to left dislocation of DPs but it is prototypical of left-hand satellites in general. As de Wit (1997) observes, CLD is also sensitive to this:

(86)
*Ik/mij die kent Jan niet.
I/me that knows Jan not

In fact, others have noticed the similarities between these constructions and CLD and CLLD. Giusti's (1996) analysis for the doubling construction assimilates the pattern to the Romance left dislocation structure. She proposes that the DP-possessor parallels the topicalized constituent in the CLLD pattern and occupies the specifier of a TopP in the DP domain. The doubling possessive pronoun in her analysis corresponds to the doubling clitic. Though this analysis is on the right track, Haegeman (2001) discusses some points that need refinement. For one thing, we cannot always identify the preposed possessor with the topic in the CLLD constructions. In CLLD constructions, typically, the dislocated DP cannot be a bare quantifier:

(87)
*Personne je ne l’ai vu.
nobody I not him have seen

According to Haegeman (2001), in West Flemish the doubling pronoun may be a bare N-quantifier, in which case the DP has the features of an indefinite DP, witness the obligatory expletive construction in (88b):

(88)
a. dat zyn niemand zen zoaken
that are no one his business
b. Niemand zen voader zou ter da keunen verdroagen.
no one his parents would there that be able to support
The topicalized element in a CLLD construction can also be a strong pronoun, an option which is at best extremely marginal for the possessor construction:

(89)
a. Lui je ne l’ai pas vu.
him I not him have not seen
‘As for him, I have not seen him.’
b. *T’is zie eur boek.
it is she her book

Another argument against assimilating the doubled DP to the topic is that the doubled DP may also be an interrogative element, which is compatible with focus interpretation (i.e., new information), but not with topic interpretation (i.e., ‘given information’):

(90)
Wien zenen boek is da?
who his book is that

The variety of elements that can double the possessor pronoun suggest that they cannot just be seen as DP-topics. Below we shall propose that the doubling construction may indeed involve some form of topicalization inside the DP, but that, contrary to what seems to be suggested by Giusti, it need not always do so.
In fact, Haegeman (2001) takes (91) to support the parallelism between dislocation and doubling possessives: 17

(91)
Over minister-president v.A. die zijn fouten hebben we gepraat.
about prime minister v.A. that his mistakes have we talked

In (91) the possessive DP minister-president v.A. is actually doubled by two elements. (i) Immediately adjacent to it there is the doubling die-pronoun which also typically occurs in the left periphery of the Dutch clause and precedes the finite verb. (ii) In addition there is the possessive pronoun zijn in POSS. Given this close parallelism between Dutch dislocation and doubling possessives in (91), Haegeman takes the Dutch pattern as the closest clausal parallel for the doubling construction.
The example offers an exact match for the dislocation structure as shown by the schematic patterns in (92):

(92)
a. Jan die vertrekt
Jan die leaves
b. Jan die z’n vertrek
Jan die his departure

While the data do confirm Giusti's intuition that the doubling construction finds a parallel in the dislocation pattern, we also see that the die pronoun in the dislocation pattern does not correspond to the possessive itself. In fact, (91) suggests that the matching elements in ‘third’ position are the finite verb in the clause and the pronoun in the DP.

By analogy with the split CP, Haegeman (2001) assumes a split DP, i.e., the category D is in fact a shorthand for a hierarchically organized set of functional projections. Haegeman proposes that the DP-internal category which encodes (in)definiteness corresponds to FinP in the CP layer. In the same way that FinP can be dominated by TopP and by FocP, the relevant projection DP can be dominated by TopP. Adapting Corver's DP structure along the lines of Rizzi's split CP she proposes the following representation for the DP in (93):

The question arises how to represent possessive structures without the doubling die pronoun. Based on the analogy with the clausal domain and assuming that possessors are subject analogues, Haegeman proposes that in the absence of an overt die pronoun the doubling possessor may still be inserted in the specifier of the TopP and that that there is a null pronominal under [Spec,D-FinP]:

p.span: 1 For a discussion on the status of epithets as resumptive elements see Aoun and Engdahl (1985), McCloskey (1990), Demirdache (1991), Shlonsky (1992), Choueiri (1999).
2 Van Riemsdijk (1997a) points out that there is a partial correlation between movement properties and connectedness.
3 Note that case connectivity is possible between the LD-ed noun phrase in Greek HTLD and the clitic. The point here is that it is not obligatory as is the case with CLLD.

4 In a system like Rizzi's (1997), HTLD elements would occur in the highest topic construction, while CLLD elements would occupy lower topic positions. According to Rizzi, topic projections hosting CLLD elements can be multiple.
5 The literature on CLLD is very rich (see Cinque 1990c; Iatridou 1994; Zubizarreta 1998, among many others and references therein).

6 The discussion on CLLD does not include the status of preverbal subjects in pro-drop languages, which have been argued by some researchers to be in a CLLD-ed position (see Alexiadou and Anagnostopoulou 1998 and references therein). Their A vs. A′ status is still a matter of controversy (see Cardinaletti 1997).
7 It is generally assumed that focus movement applies much like wh-movement (see Cinque 1990c; Rizzi 1997).

8 Demirdache (1991) points out that the immunity to WCO simply shows that the pronoun does not have the interpretation of a logical variable. It does not show that the construction does not involve wh-movement.

9 Though the two approaches share certain common properties, they differ in the details. For instance, Iatridou assumes that it is the dislocated XP that undergoes A′-movement, whereas Demirdache assumes that the dislocated XP is generated in the position where it appears at S-structures and it is the IP-internal pronoun that undergoes movement. Second, Iatridou assumes that movement takes place at S-structure, whereas Demirdache proposes that movement takes place at LF. However, both share the property of suggesting that CLLD is selective sensitive to islands because movement originates from an A′-position.

10 Aoun and Benmamoun further propose that the type of movement involved in CLLD in Lebanese Arabic takes place actually at the PF component. Specifically, pre-spell-out the CLLD-ed NP remains in the specifier of a clitic phrase, an A-position, therefore no interception with wh-movement and topicalization is observed. A PF movement operation does not feed LF. At LF the CLLD-ed element is still located in the specifier of the clitic phrase. Hence the “reconstruction effects.”
11 Anagnostopoulou shows that the Condition C effects do not disappear under clitic doubling, hence providing an argument that CLLD cannot be reduced to clitic doubling.

12 The specifics of the overall analysis of Agouraki are crucially different. In the spirit of Sportiche (1996b), Agouraki (1993) proposes that clitics are functional heads heading their own projection and they may co-occur with full DPs in argument positions (clitic doubling). The doubled DPs may raise overtly to the specifier of the clitic head and from there they can move further on (CLLD). Agouraki points out that CLLD has mixed A/A′ properties, similar to scrambling. She proposes to account for this similarity by postulating that the movement step of the DP to the clitic position has A properties (akin to an agreement process) while movement beyond this domain has A′ properties (cf. Mahajan 1990 for short-, medium-, and long-distance scrambling; Sportiche 1996b, who proposes to unify the syntax of clitic constructions and scrambling; and Alexiadou and Anagnostopoulou 1997a, who argue that the counterpart of short scrambling is clitic doubling, substantiating Sportiche's claim with evidence from binding).

13 There is an obvious parallelism between the structure of relative clauses and that of left-dislocated constructions. This is particularly true in languages such as Dutch and German: both relative clauses and CLD are characterized by a nominal head and a fronted d-pronoun (see the contributions in Anagnostopoulou et al. 1997).
14 Zwart (1993: 250) points out that this example is not very bad under a restricted reading.
15 Vat (1997) contains a discussion of the derivation of CLD by comparing the T-model to the NP-Structure model of Van Riemsdijk and Williams (1981).

16 Note, however, that given recent proposals about the set of functional categories that form the left periphery of a clause embedded CLLD-ed phrases could be argued to be situated on specifiers of functional projections within the C system.
17 Note that at least some speakers of Standard Dutch judge the example as ungrammatical.
